content: I've flown international business class with most of the major airlines this year. Here's my ranking 1. Qatar - Everything feels like flying first class - For Ex. How do they keep a filet perfectly medium rare for that long (sous vide is the only explination I have). But please, this movie selection is horrendous. And loungewear for long haul flights is nice. @qatarairways 2. Emirates - Excellent food and beverage, great service, entertainment selection is great. Bed is very comfortable. @emirates 3. Turkish - Good - I like the black color motif, food and service are good, spacious cabin. @TurkishAirlines 4. United - Decent overall but Polaris is incredibly cramped. Food and beverage is good, but not excellent. Entertainment is great with big list of Hollywood films. @united 5. Air France, British and Lufthansa are all just ok 6. Ethiopian - honrable mention because I like injera. Other business class I've flown is basically a step up from premium economy. Royal Air Maroc, Royal Brunei Airlines, Thai Airways International, and many other country specific airlines. I've flown alot this year, and while I don't enjoy the 16+ hr flights, I've just decided to enjoy the small details that make it less miserable. #travel #airlines

content: I've been musing about the changes to the British Airways "Club" from my cabin here in the Yukon. Clearly this was inevitable. With the change to Avios earning being revenue based, this was always going to happen, it was simply a question of when, and how bad the change was going to be. I am struck though by how 'Delta' like the changes are. Perhaps BA/IAG have grown a pair and figured given their network and fortress hub position at LHR, people will fly them regardless, so tough cookies to all of their customers. I think perhaps the trans-Atlantic joint-business had some input into it too, as clearly it was much harder to get status for an EXP or CK than it was Gold or GGL given the hard spend requirements for Loyalty Points. The sad thing is, I think BA may actually be right about people sticking with them. Look at the Lufthansa Group for example. Lufthansa business class is rubbish. Swiss is ok. Coupled with the fact that Miles & More (unless you're HON Circle), is pretty mediocre, and certainly not as good as the Exec Club was, yet people still fly Lufthansa Group because they and United/Air Canada offer non-stop products in the markets with which they serve. Miles & More's switch to a points based system took some elements of the BA programme, but didn't take any of the gamification of the Exec Club that enables tier point running. So it's somewhat of a half-way house and therefore not as engaging. My predictions for 2025 are that BA and IAG will largely stay the course for this one. However I do predict some kind of mid-year tier point credit (perhaps July/August time), like Lufthansa did, when it's clear that fewer people will requalify. However I don't think there will be a significant impact to bookings. The 'US3' and to some extent the Lufthansa changes show us that people will stick with them regardless. So more heat than light for probably longer than people expect, but no big impact to the IAG FY results in 2025.

content: @PauloNoggy This itinerary isn't a saver route; it's to maintain my gold status for another two years. In the long run, I benefit from free upgrades, first class check-in even when flying economy, lounge access (including the Concorde Room and First Class Lounge even when flying economy), unlocking preferred seats on certain routes, free seat selection across all oneworld airlines(which for Qatar in biz can cost ¬£75 per seat), and free 2 x 32kg baggage allowance for me and everyone I book for, regardless of class, on all airlines. These perks save me a lot overall and can be used with any oneworld airline, not just British Airways. The itinerary cost me ¬£340, with two of the flights costing just ¬£1 each and the rest paid for with Avios. I also took advantage of the BA sales that ended yesterday.

content: An American Airlines flight from Las Vegas to Dallas turned chaotic when a flight attendant suddenly locked herself in the galley and called police on multiple first-class passengers mid-flight. Shocked travelers say the confrontation started over simple drink requests that spiraled out of control. Before takeoff, the pilot had already warned passengers that ‚Äúno rudeness toward flight attendants would be tolerated,‚Äù setting an oddly tense tone for Flight AA3286. Once in the air, service in first class was delayed for more than an hour while those in economy had already been served, frustrating passengers who say they had done nothing wrong. The bizarre incident happened on October 4th, 2025, aboard an Airbus A321 headed for Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport (DFW). Witnesses say the flight attendant became defensive and accused a passenger of reporting her to the captain, which he denied. She then told the captain that customers were ‚Äúmean,‚Äù ‚Äúbelligerent,‚Äù and ‚Äúprobably drunk,‚Äù before locking herself in the galley and refusing to continue service. When the plane landed, she read up to ten passenger names over the PA system, announcing that police would meet them at the gate. Officers did meet the plane but reportedly laughed after hearing what happened and left without taking action. Police later advised airline staff not to use law enforcement as a threat toward passengers. American Airlines has since confirmed an internal investigation is underway.

content: @Kokomoschmoe He sounds like my aunts and uncles. Not so much my parents, which is weird. Definitely my cousins also. Pittsburghese, or Western Pennsylvania English, is a distinct American dialect centered in Pittsburgh, known for unique vocabulary (like "yinz" for you all, "buggy" for shopping cart, "jimmies" for sprinkles) and pronunciation influenced by Scots-Irish, German, Slavic, and other immigrant groups, creating a mix of unique phrases and an iconic, often nasal, accent with terms like "nebby" (nosy) and "needs fixed". Key Features ‚Ä¢Vocabulary: Words like "dahntahn" (downtown), "red up" (clean up), "clicker" (remote), and "slippy" (slippery) are common. ‚Ä¢Pronunciation: A unique nasal quality, particularly in vowels, with a distinctive "ah" sound, and mergers like "cot" and "caught". ‚Ä¢Grammar: Usage of "whenever" for specific times ("Whenever I get home...") and the "needs fixed" construction ("The car needs washed"). ‚Ä¢Influences: A blend of Scots-Irish, German, Slavic, African American, and even Old Norse, from waves of immigration. ‚Ä¢Identity: Strongly associated with the working-class community, with speakers called "Yinzers," and celebrated through local culture like t-shirts and media. Examples ‚Ä¢Yinz: "Yinz wanna go for a buggy ride?" (You all want to go for a shopping cart ride?). ‚Ä¢Red up: "I gotta red up the house." (I have to clean up the house). ‚Ä¢Jimmies: "Put some jimmies on that ice cream." (Put sprinkles on that ice cream). Origin and Spread Originating in the 18th century with Scots-Irish settlers, it absorbed influences from subsequent immigrant groups, solidifying into a unique dialect by the mid-20th century, with its distinctiveness becoming a point of local pride and study for linguists. Curt Cignetti was born June 2, 1961, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He is the son of Hall-of-Fame coach Frank Cignetti Sr. Cignetti played quarterback for the West Virginia Mountaineers from 1979 to 1982 under head coaches Frank Cignetti Sr. and Don Nehlen. Actor Jimmy Stewart is from Indiana, Pennsylvania. I never heard anyone I was related to use the words Jimmies or Buggies. James Stewart was often called Jimmy. Although I never met the man, I did see him board a flight from Los Angeles to New York on an American Airlines 747 I was loading bags on down below on the ramp. content: Selon un article que j‚Äôai lu r√©cemment, les pratiques de restauration √† bord varient beaucoup selon les compagnies a√©riennes. √Ä partir de janvier 2025, @airfrance testera des repas payants en classe √©conomique sur certaines liaisons, tout en continuant de proposer des repas gratuits sur les vols long-courriers. D'autres compagnies comme Corsair, Qatar Airways, et Lufthansa offrent des repas gratuits en classe √©conomique sur tous leurs vols, avec parfois plusieurs options et des menus adapt√©s aux r√©gimes sp√©cifiques. Par exemple, @CorsairFr inclut repas et boissons gratuits sur tous ses vols, et propose des menus th√©matiques payants. @British_Airways , sur ses vols long-courriers, fournit des repas en classe √©conomique, tandis que sur les vols courts, seuls les passagers de classe affaires en b√©n√©ficient. @EGYPTAIR et @qatarairways offrent des repas halal gratuits, avec plusieurs choix de plats. En revanche, les compagnies low-cost comme @Ryanair , EasyJet et @vueling ne fournissent pas de repas gratuits, et les passagers doivent payer s‚Äôils souhaitent manger √† bord. Bref, certaines compagnies maintiennent la gratuit√© des repas, tandis que d'autres adoptent des mod√®les payants, notamment sur les vols court et moyen-courriers, ce qui influence l'exp√©rience de voyage et peut impacter le choix de la compagnie.

content: I booked my flight #LH631 from Dubai to Frankfurt with @lufthansa in economy class. Later, I upgraded my flight to business class. I asked for assistance via chat, and they told me that checked luggage was not allowed, so I discarded my checked luggage. However, yesterday, they told me I was allowed to have two pieces of carry-on luggage plus a computer. Today, I wanted to verify this via chat, and they told me I could only have one piece of carry-on luggage, so I discarded the second carry-on. What is happening with Lufthansa? Have you experienced this with your frequent travel? I'm a United 1K and Star Alliance Gold member. If you pay for a business class upgrade, you should at least have the minimum baggage allowance and receive consistent responses from your chat assistance, not different answers every day

content: I've flown international business class with most of the major airlines this year. Here's my ranking 1. Qatar - Everything feels like flying first class - For Ex. How do they keep a filet perfectly medium rare for that long (sous vide is the only explination I have). But please, this movie selection is horrendous. And loungewear for long haul flights is nice. @qatarairways 2. Emirates - Excellent food and beverage, great service, entertainment selection is great. They make you feel special and bed is very comfortable. @emirates 3. Turkish - Good - I like the black color motif, food and service are good, spacious cabin. @TurkishAirlines 4. United - Decent overall but Polaris is incredibly cramped. Food and beverage is good, but not excellent. Entertainment is great with big list of Hollywood films. @united 5. Air France, British and Lufthansa are all just ok 6. Ethiopian - honrable mention because I like injera. Other business class I've flown is basically a step up from premium economy. Royal Air Maroc, Royal Brunei Airlines, Thai Airways International, and many other country specific airlines. I've flown alot this year, and while I don't enjoy the 16+ hr flights, I've just decided to enjoy the small details that make it less miserable. #travel #airlinesThey

content: Air France has announced that starting in the summer of 2025, it will begin offering high-speed WiFi on select flights through a partnership with Starlink. This service will gradually be introduced across various routes, including regional ones, and will be complimentary for all passengers. The WiFi service aims to replicate the connectivity experience one would expect on the ground, allowing passengers to maintain communication, keep up with news, engage in online gaming, and stream media during their flight. The service will support multiple device connections per passenger, accessible via smartphones, tablets, and laptops. To use the WiFi, passengers will need to log in with their Flying Blue account, though first-class travelers can access it directly without login. For those without an account, one can be created at no cost after boarding. This initiative comes alongside Air France's recent decision to experiment with a paid √† la carte meal service on certain European routes, moving away from complimentary in-flight meals. The connectivity will be provided by Starlink's extensive network of low-earth orbit satellites, which ensures wide coverage, with the exception of areas where internet use is restricted. This follows similar moves by airlines like Hawaiian Airlines, which started its Starlink service in February 2024, and United Airlines, which has partnered with SpaceX for similar purposes.

content: @queru_lant ‚ÄûLachsmilys‚Äú h√∂rt sich wie etwas an, was in der Speisekarte der Lufthansa Business Class vorkommt. üòâ

Ever feel like your house is in a flight simulator? You're not alone. Let‚Äôs talk airplane noise. It‚Äôs one of those things people either shrug off or passionately debate like pineapple on pizza or whether socks belong with sandals. But for some of us, it‚Äôs not just a background hum... it‚Äôs a full-blown soundtrack to our lives. Now, before anyone jumps in with ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt you know there was an airport when you bought your house?‚Äù Yes, I did. But here‚Äôs the thing: noise is a symptom, not the root cause. It‚Äôs like having a fever, it tells you something‚Äôs up. And lately, something is up. My Noise vs. Your Noise I live in a low flyover zone about 3.5 miles from the airport. I‚Äôve lived in three different homes in this area since 2014, and I swear the noise has changed, especially in the last two years. It‚Äôs not just louder; it‚Äôs different. The recent United expansion got me curious, so I started digging into the data. I‚Äôve compiled a report for September 2025 using info from the airport‚Äôs own monitoring tools. This focuses on my area, using readings from monitors along the departure and arrival routes. If you live near Black Rail Road or Vista Fire Station #5, you‚Äôd need to check your own local data to see how it compares. Tools You Can Use ‚Ä¢ Noise Dashboard: Created by the San Marcos PAAC rep (with help from the airport manager, I suspect), this dashboard is a goldmine for noise nerds like me. You can explore real data and trends here: üëâ Noise Dashboard: https://t.co/BnWHVAwT1Y ‚Ä¢ WebTrak: Want to know what just roared over your house? WebTrak lets you track flights and noise levels. There‚Äôs a 15‚Äì30-minute delay, so jot down the time you heard it and use the replay feature. üëâ WebTrak: https://t.co/BVExdCFbNv What‚Äôs That Sound? Let‚Äôs break it down: ‚Ä¢ Small Prop Planes: These are the quiet buzzers. Unless they‚Äôre doing aerial acrobatics or having a bad day, they‚Äôre barely noticeable. Think of them as the Prius of the skies. ‚Ä¢ Turboprops: These guys sound like angry weed whackers. They can hit 70‚Äì75 dB, which is loud enough to pause a conversation or make your dog give you the side-eye. ‚Ä¢ Midsize Jets: Your typical business-class birds. They hum like a small industrial machine and get louder as they approach. Not ear-shattering, but definitely noticeable. ‚Ä¢ Big Jets (JSX, AA, etc.): These are the heavy hitters. JSX jets average around 75 dB over my neighborhood, and American Airlines jets can hit 80 dB‚Äîcomparable to a Harley or a loud air compressor. Not dangerous for your hearing in short bursts, but enough to spike your blood pressure or make you forget what you were saying. ‚Ä¢ Aggressive Maneuvers: My personal least favorite. These sudden, loud flyovers feel like the sky is yelling at you. They‚Äôve become more frequent, possibly due to air traffic control managing tighter flight paths. I‚Äôve started documenting these in hopes someone can help figure out a solution. What the Data Says I‚Äôve attached a summary of this month‚Äôs WebTrak report. Over the past three months, noise events have increased by 15% compared to last year, with September alone up 9% over September 2024. But here‚Äôs the kicker: complaints have skyrocketed, especially since the new monitor was installed near Loker Ave. Vista went from 4 to 197 complaints. San Marcos, despite being one of the most impacted areas, shows fewer complaints. Why? Maybe the complaint system doesn‚Äôt recognize our addresses (I‚Äôve tried!), or maybe we‚Äôre a windows-shut, grin-and-bear-it kind of crowd. I live about 1,200 feet from the monitor and hear planes often. Most don‚Äôt bother me, except those dive-bombers. Those are next-level annoying. Final Thought Noise isn‚Äôt just about volume, it‚Äôs about impact. If you‚Äôve noticed changes or have insights into the odd data trends, I‚Äôd love to hear from you. Let‚Äôs keep the conversation going (when the jets aren‚Äôt interrupting us).

content: @ERAUBusinessDB https://t.co/KvecviUUvh QT @archeohistories: In 1987, Steve Rothstein made a decision that seemed almost outrageous at the time: he paid \$250,000 for American Airlines‚Äô unlimited ‚Äúgolden ticket,‚Äù granting him free first-class flights for life. On top of that, he purchased a \$150,000 companion pass so he could bring anyone along. For Steve, travel wasn‚Äôt about collecting miles or rewards‚Äîit was about freedom without limits, and he used it to the fullest. Over the years, Rothstein booked more than 10,000 flights, sometimes hopping on a plane just to have lunch in another state before returning home the same day. He was known for his generosity, often giving away trips to strangers, helping homeless individuals reunite with their families, or booking seats for companions who never showed up. His unusual habits made him both a legend and a financial headache, as American Airlines eventually calculated that he had cost them over \$21 million. In 2008, the airline revoked his pass, accusing him of misuse. But Rothstein fought back, pointing to the binding contract he had purchased decades earlier. The courts sided with him, and his golden ticket remained valid. Today, Steve Rothstein is remembered not only as the most extraordinary frequent flyer but also as a symbol of how one small clause in a contract can unlock the entire world. ¬© Aviation History #archaeohistories

content: @AmericanAir has demonstrated highly unsatisfactory customer service. My family of nine, who had pre-selected seats together for our international travel months in advance, found our seating arrangements changed, resulting in us being dispersed across the plane due to updates made by American Airlines. Upon contacting customer service to rectify this issue, I encountered two representatives who attempted to impose additional charges per ticket, despite the seats not being in first class. Furthermore, when I politely requested to escalate the matter to a higher supervisor, the call was abruptly disconnected. It is clear that American Airlines prioritizes profit over customer satisfaction, particularly when the airline itself was responsible for the disruption. I would advise against using @AmericanAir for your travel needs!

content: @OneMileataTime Transatlantic, we've only splurged eastbound overnight business class flights to sleep... but that never seems to work out because we want to enjoy the service (especially Air France). We're lucky if we can get 3 hours rest because of the short flight time, but it is comfy. TBH, KLM's new Premium Economy is an excellent substitute when their BC redemptions are too high and hope for a last minute upgrade opportunity on money or points. I find it harder to justify a daytime westbound in business class, even from a carriers hub. We'll fly economy, last row of preferred in an aisle/window hoping the middle stays open and order a premium meal (KLM FTW) and watch the same movies together.

content: @fretfretfret @HansMokeNiemann Ach, here's yer chess lad's travel tale in proper Scottish patter: Ah wanted tae spill the beans on whit a chess player's life's really like. Afore Wijk Aan Zee, ah thocht ah'd nip intae Vienna on the way, an' ah snagged a braw cheap business class ticket. Trip started aff smooth as, ah rocked up early tae the airport, but they wanted a printed boarding pass. Nae wifi, but a fan spotted me, so ah offered a photie if he'd share his hotspot. Sorted! Checked in, but they said equipment shortage meant a plane swap, bumpin' me doon tae economy. The auld yin had 14 fancy seats, new yin only 8, so six o' us drew the short straw. They were decent, blocked aff a hale row in economy, still a bit mingin' though. No' a nightmare yet, but jist the start. Landed in Abu Dhabi, lookin' forward tae a comfy seat tae Vienna. But the captain pipes up "10 minutes tae landin'", half an hour later, nae landin'. Weather's pure howlin', so we're circlin' like eejits. Efter an hour, plan wis Munich, but we end up in Frankfurt. They said same plane back tae Vienna at 8pm. Ah spied an 11:45 flight earlier, booked it tae save time. 'Course, it gets cancelled an hour afore, an' aw ither flights full. Lufthansa rebooks me tae Dusseldorf then Vienna. Efter 24 hours o' travel hell, cancellations, dosh doon the pan, ah take it an' arrive at 7pm. Ye might think this is pure doom an' gloom, but it's a grand sign for ma chess! Whenever these travel stooshies hit, especially in the pandemic, braw results followed. So aw ma bad luck's oot, an' things should gang ma way noo!

content: @toryboypierce @British_Airways Sadly it‚Äôs not the Same anymore Andrew. Read my experience few days ago. I really don‚Äôt wish anyone to go through this. It felt like flying with Ryanair with that kind of customer service. https://t.co/SCfM22y8bs QT @sash_jpg: A story about @British_Airways I had a flight booked for Thursday to see my dad, who was extremely unwell with Alzheimer‚Äôs disease. Sadly, on Sunday, he passed away. I contacted British Airways customer service, and they told me not to worry they could move me to an earlier flight. The only option available connected via Nairobi. As it was a 26-hour journey, I asked to upgrade to the maximum possible. I was told there was no Business Class available, despite my return ticket being Business (Club World). The agent who helped rebook the flight reassured me and specifically said, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, you‚Äôll be able to use our lounges during the connection.‚Äù When I arrived in Nairobi, no one could tell me which lounge I was allowed to use. The British Airways team said their lounge was only available if I was upgraded to Club World again. Their connecting flight partner said I couldn‚Äôt use their lounge either. None of my cards Amex, Revolut Gold, or anything else worked. I messaged British Airways repeatedly, explaining that I was stuck in the airport, hadn‚Äôt eaten for two days, and was travelling immediately after losing my father. I didn‚Äôt asked for any other help, I just needed somewhere to rest. There was zero empathy and no effort to resolve the situation. Almost no concern at all. Even your cabin crew were shocked that no hotel, lounge access, or basic support had been arranged for me. So thank you, British Airways. You can call yourself whatever kind of airline you want but when I needed you the most, you didn‚Äôt show up. In the end I upgraded my connection flight via their partner airline directly. The lesson here: don‚Äôt waste your time on loyalty. It doesn‚Äôt pay nor it comes when you need it the most. And drop those Amex gold bullshit, nothing helps when it‚Äôs urgent urgent.

content: Black First-Class Passenger Sues Delta Air Lines Over Alleged Racial Discrimination - Travel Noire https://t.co/zhsWIZWYgH

The weird stories you find onlineüëâüëâ A British Airways flight attendant, Haden Pentecost, was found naked and under the influence of methamphetamine and amphetamines in an airplane bathroom during a flight from San Francisco to London in May 2025. Pentecost was a member of the cabin crew, not a passenger, and was on duty at the time of the incident. Details of the incident: ‚Ä¢Behavior: Colleagues described him as "dishevelled, pale, sweaty and erratic" before he locked himself in the business class lavatory. When he emerged, he was "completely naked and oblivious" to the fact, babbling incoherently. ‚Ä¢Response: A co-worker dressed him and moved him to an empty seat. The captain was alerted, and a medical professional on board was called to monitor him for the rest of the flight. ‚Ä¢Aftermath: Upon landing at Heathrow Airport, paramedics met the aircraft and took him to the hospital. Blood tests confirmed the presence of methamphetamine and amphetamines in his system. He was later dismissed by British Airways. ‚Ä¢Legal Outcome: Pentecost pleaded guilty to performing an aviation function while impaired by drugs. In September 2025, he received a six-month prison sentence, suspended for a year, along with 80 hours of unpaid work. The judge noted that no passengers were aware of his condition during the flight.

content: When One Seat Goes Viral, It Exposes an Industry Problem‚Äù A short video showing generous legroom on a WestJet flight out of Edmonton went viral for a simple reason: people were shocked that economy class could still look humane. That reaction says more about today‚Äôs airline industry than about one airplane seat. Passengers have been conditioned to expect shrinking legroom, extra fees for basic comfort, and cabins designed more for revenue optimization than human dignity. So when a single seat offers space to breathe, stretch, and exist without apology, it feels like an exception‚Äîalmost a miracle. This was likely an exit row or a specific aircraft configuration, not a system-wide policy change. But that‚Äôs precisely the point. Comfort has been elevated to a privilege, rather than a standard. Airlines sell ‚Äúextra‚Äù legroom as if dignity were a luxury add-on rather than a baseline expectation. The viral video didn‚Äôt celebrate WestJet. It exposed how low the bar has fallen. When basic comfort becomes newsworthy, the industry should ask itself a hard question: When did treating passengers like cargo become normal? Because people aren‚Äôt asking for first class. They‚Äôre asking for space to sit‚Äîwithout viral proof that it‚Äôs even possible. #CPRMRadio #EditorialCartoon #SymbolicArt #AirlineIndustry #PassengerRights #TravelReality #EconomyClass #Legroom #ComfortVsProfit #HumanDignity #ModernTravel #WhatWentWrong

content: In 1987, Rothstein purchased the ‚ÄòAAirpass‚Äô from American Airlines for $250,000 which allowed him to fly first class for life at no additional cost. American Airlines cancelled his pass in 2008 because they claimed he booked excessive flights and misused the system. Although he sought legal action, his pass was never renewed. Rothstein‚Äôs situation is what encouraged American Airlines to abolish their unlimited pass program. #americanairlines #airoplane

@Turbinetraveler Iet me think this through out loud, the way I do when I‚Äôm alone at 3 a.m. staring at old photos of G-BOAF on the runway at Filton. First, the crash. Air France 4590, 25 July 2000. A strip of metal on the runway, a burst tyre, a fuel tank ripped open, fire, 113 dead. Horrible. Unforgivable in the sense that it was preventable. The investigation was brutal in its honesty: the tank design had a known vulnerability, the spacer strips between the ply layers in the tyres were missing on some wheels, runway debris discipline at CDG was lax. The fixes came fast‚ÄîKevlar liners in the tanks, better tyres, Michelin NZGs that wouldn‚Äôt shred the same way, FOD walks on runways, even little deflectors ahead of the gear. By 2001 the fleet was back in the air, certificates renewed. And people flew. Loads were solid. Celebrities, bankers, the merely rich who wanted New York breakfast and London dinner. I‚Äôve talked to cabin crew from those last two years‚Äîthey said the mood on board was almost defiant, like ‚Äúwe‚Äôre still here.‚Äù Then the numbers. This is where I start to waver. A Concorde overhaul cost roughly the same as buying a new widebody. Fuel burn was monstrous‚Äîfour times a 747 per seat. The ozone scare (later mostly debunked) and the post-9/11 drop in premium travel hurt badly. Airbus announced they‚Äôd stop supporting the A300-600 airframe donor parts, and without Airbus the Type Certificate was toast. British Airways and Air France looked at the ledger and quietly concluded that even at $12,000 a ticket they were losing money on every flight once you rolled in the capital costs. But‚Ä¶ but. Today I can drop $15‚Äì25k on a Qatar Qsuite or an Emirates first-class shower suite and barely blink, because half the cabin is paying it. London‚ÄìNew York business class is routinely $8‚Äì12k round-trip now, often more. The infra has improved‚Äîbetter runways, better ATC, quieter engines were already in development (the ‚ÄúOlympus 593 Mk 610‚Äù that never flew would have cut noise dramatically). Carbon brakes, fly-by-wire retrofits‚Äînone of it impossible. Expensive, yes. Absurdly so? Maybe not, if someone had really wanted it. This is where the doubt creeps in. Because no one did want it enough. Not the airlines (BA was bleeding cash post-9/11), not the manufacturers (Airbus wanted out), not the regulators (the FAA never gave full domestic overland rights anyway), and‚Äîhere‚Äôs the part that stings‚Äînot the public either. We mourned her, we bought the posters, but we didn‚Äôt march in the streets or refuse to fly subsonic. We posted grainy videos on YouTube and moved on. Was it politics? In a way, yes. The loudest anti-Concorde voices were always political‚Äîgreen groups who hated the fuel burn, American airlines who hated the competitive threat and lobbied against overland routes, French and British governments quietly relieved to be rid of a prestige project that had become a money pit. The crash simply handed everyone the perfect excuse they were waiting for. I go back and forth. One day I‚Äôm convinced she could have been saved‚Äîre-engine with something derived from the Trent, sell 10 refurbished airframes to boutique operators for $20‚Äì30k a seat, turn her into the ultimate Veblen good. The next day I look at the maintenance logs and think, ‚ÄúMy God, what a fragile, thirsty, noisy beast‚Äîshe was a miracle we got 27 years out of her.‚Äù Maybe the truth is gentler than conspiracy and harsher than nostalgia: Concorde represented a moment when governments and companies were still willing to lose money for the way people lose money on art‚Äîbecause beauty and ambition mattered. That moment passed. Not because of one crash, not because of one Airworthiness Directive, but because we slowly, quietly, decided that three-and-a-half hours from London to New York wasn‚Äôt worth the poetry anymore. And yet every time I see that delta wing against a sunset, I feel the same thing I felt as a child a tug in the chest that says we gave up something irreplaceable. Not just speed.

content: @_6954_ @thegoodbrother0 @WallStreetMav It was too expensive to most humans. How I got my trip was a bit of a fluke. I was living in France at the time, but traveling a lot to the US. I usually tried to use British Airways (back when BA actually was BA). I had a flight to Boston. Flew from Paris to London, and found that the flight had been cancelled. Stood in the long line to get another flight. There was only one guy handling it all. The two (Americans) in front of me were quite unpleasant to him. Something to do with being put in economy rather than business class, to JFK. My turn came. I took pit on him. I smiled and said: "My flight seems to have been cancelled, what can we do about it?" He was surprised that I didn't abuse him like everyone else. He rattled his keyboard ... "How about ... a flight to DC, then a connecting flight to Boston?" "Yes, that will work. " "Oh, the flight to DC is on Concorde ... not a problem is it?" "No, I think I can deal with that." Being pleasant to people can pay off.

content: Thank God there are still so many good people in the world! https://t.co/yNrGwPcwUE QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I can‚Äôt help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say it‚Äôs just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesn‚Äôt know I‚Äôm back. They tell me that I‚Äôm going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. I‚Äôm pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, ‚ÄúHow much is it?‚Äù They tell him $50 and he says ‚ÄúI got it.‚Äù I‚Äôm astonished and tell him it‚Äôs fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this man‚Äôs generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. I‚Äôm crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as he‚Äôs sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." üíï Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

content: üìâ Inflation bites. üõçÔ∏è The wealthy keep spending. ü§ñ AI carries the market. ‚öñÔ∏è And Washington is playing with fire. The search for stability has led investors to an unexpected place: economic data. After months of disruption, US inflation data is finally back on schedule ‚Äî and it delivers an uncomfortable truth. üî∏ CPI is running at 2.7% üî∏ Beef prices up 16% üî∏ Natural gas up ~11% üî∏ Eating out rising at an 8%+ annual pace Think of inflation like a slow leak in your wallet. You don‚Äôt notice it every day ‚Äî until the bills start piling up. That pressure hasn‚Äôt gone away for ordinary Americans. Yet here‚Äôs the paradox‚Ä¶ üí≥ Premium spending is alive and well Earnings season tells a different story ‚Äî especially at the top end. JPMorgan Chase beat expectations across most of its business lines. CEO Jamie Dimon struck an unusually calm tone: üî∏ Consumers are still spending üî∏ Businesses remain healthy üî∏ Labour markets have softened ‚Äî but not cracked Now look at airlines. Delta Air Lines missed some forecasts, and the stock was punished ‚Äî yet management made one thing crystal clear: üî∏ Almost all future growth comes from premium customers In plain terms: The economy is splitting in two. Those at the top are still flying first class. Everyone else is feeling turbulence. üìä Markets are unforgiving right now So far this earnings season: üî∏ Only a few companies missed expectations üî∏ But those misses were punished twice as hard as usual Think of the market like a stressed referee ‚Äî no second chances, no benefit of the doubt. ü§ñ AI is carrying the scoreboard Wall Street expects S&P 500 earnings to grow ~8%, marking a 10th straight quarter of growth. But peel back the curtain and you see something crucial: üî∏ Most optimism is concentrated in tech üî∏ And tech optimism is concentrated in AI üî∏ And AI expectations are concentrated in one company That company is Nvidia. Remove Nvidia, and tech‚Äôs earnings growth drops sharply. Analogy time: The market is riding a single engine at cruising altitude. It‚Äôs powerful ‚Äî but everyone is watching that engine very closely. If Nvidia stumbles, Mr Market won‚Äôt be forgiving. ‚öñÔ∏è Meanwhile in Washington: a dangerous game As all this unfolds, political pressure on the Federal Reserve is escalating. President Donald Trump has publicly attacked Fed Chair Jerome Powell, even as DOJ subpoenas hover in the background. This matters more than most people realise. When politicians threaten central bank independence, markets hear one thing: üî∏ Higher inflation expectations üî∏ Higher long-term interest rates üî∏ A weaker currency over time As Jamie Dimon put it plainly: Interference backfires. It‚Äôs like yelling at a thermostat and expecting the room to cool down faster ‚Äî instead, you blow the fuse. ü™ô The old lesson returns History keeps repeating itself: üî∏ Rising debt üî∏ Political pressure üî∏ Currency dilution That‚Äôs why investors always circle back to hard assets ‚Äî especially gold ‚Äî when trust in institutions starts to fray. üß≠ Bottom line We are in a strange moment: üî∏ Inflation still hurts everyday life üî∏ The wealthy keep spending üî∏ AI is propping up markets üî∏ Politics is testing monetary credibility Stability feels scarce ‚Äî but the signals are there if you know where to look. (Source: Financial Times, FactSet, company earnings) #Inflation #EarningsSeason #AI

content: This is hilarious. https://t.co/YnFeKoyMKP QT @EUAITaxonomy: I read the news this morning. Lufthansa has signed a deal with Elon Musk‚Äôs Starlink to equip 850 aircraft with high-speed internet. The politicians are furious. I am furious. I immediately booked a flight to Frankfurt to protest at the First Class Terminal (I have Senator status, obviously). "This is a betrayal of Digital Sovereignty," I told the lounge attendant. "You are routing the data of honest European passengers through American satellites owned by a man who does not respect the Digital Services Act." "But Lars," she said. "Starlink offers 150 Mbps and low latency. The passengers want to stream Netflix." "Dr. Lars, and i must object," I replied. "Passengers do not need 'Streaming'. They need 'Compliance'." "Why did we not wait for the European alternative, IRIS¬≤? It is scheduled to be operational by 2030 (maybe). It will offer 12 Mbps, cost ‚Ç¨50 per hour, and require a Post-Ident verification via webcam to log in." "That is the European way." "Instead, you choose the American Cowboy solution." "Fast. Cheap. Functional." "Disgusting." "Have you performed a Transfer Impact Assessment (TIA) for the data packets leaving the aircraft fuselage? The troposphere is technically a third-country jurisdiction." "If I send an email over the Atlantic using a Starlink terminal, is my metadata being harvested in Texas? Where is the Schrems II compliance?" She offered me a glass of Champagne to make me stop talking. I accepted. "I will use the Starlink Wi-Fi," I whispered. "But I will browse with a VPN set to Bielefeld." We may be flying at 35,000 feet. But our data must remain grounded.

content: @CBCNews Air Canada‚Äôs new rule about not allowing carry-ons for those who buy economy or ‚Äúbasic fare‚Äù tickets really shows how much the wealthy are prioritized. I‚Äôve flown both first class & economy, and the difference is unbelievable. When I fly economy, I‚Äôm standing at check-in, desperately shifting 3 to 4 pounds in my luggage just to avoid paying extra fees. But when you‚Äôre flying first class, you get an extra suitcase AND 20 more pounds per bag‚Äîno hassle. It‚Äôs clear: if you‚Äôve got the money, you get treated way better. This new policy just adds to the divide. It‚Äôs hard to buy into the idea that ‚Äúall humans are equal‚Äù when it‚Äôs obvious that the more you pay, the better your experience is.

content: ‚ÄúPay it Forward ‚Äú in action. Happy ending! https://t.co/553O80lX9x QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I can‚Äôt help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say it‚Äôs just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesn‚Äôt know I‚Äôm back. They tell me that I‚Äôm going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. I‚Äôm pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, ‚ÄúHow much is it?‚Äù They tell him $50 and he says ‚ÄúI got it.‚Äù I‚Äôm astonished and tell him it‚Äôs fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this man‚Äôs generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. I‚Äôm crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as he‚Äôs sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." üíï Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

content: AIRPLANE WITH DOUBLE DECKERS‚Ä¶ for passengers Double-decker planes, or those with a multi-level cabin configuration, are primarily associated with two iconic aircraft: 1. **Boeing 747**: Known as the "Queen of the Skies," it has a partial upper deck, often used for first-class lounges or additional seating. This plane has been used by numerous countries for both passenger and cargo operations. However, its production has ceased, but it remains in service with airlines like Lufthansa and Korean Air for some passenger routes, and significantly in cargo versions by carriers like Atlas Air. - **Inside**: The upper deck of the 747 is smaller than the main cabin but often used for luxury or business class. It's like a VIP room in the sky where the elite can escape the common folk, but without the champagne fountains you'd expect in such an exclusive club. 2. **Airbus A380**: This is the full double-decker jetliner with both decks running the length of the fuselage. It's operated by airlines from countries like the UAE (Emirates), Singapore (Singapore Airlines), Australia (Qantas), and others. - **Inside**: The A380 is like a flying palace with its spacious interior. The upper deck is often where you'll find the swanky business and first-class cabins, sometimes with lounges and even shower spas, because why not freshen up at 35,000 feet? The main deck typically houses economy and premium economy. It's like having a party where the cool kids hang out upstairs, and the rest of us mingle with the snack bar downstairs. Countries where these planes operate include: - **United Arab Emirates**: Emirates is the largest operator of the A380, with Dubai International Airport as a major hub. - **Singapore**: Singapore Airlines, one of the first operators of the A380. - **France**: Air France has flown the A380, although they've been reducing their fleet. - **Germany**: Lufthansa has utilized both the A380 and 747-8 for long-haul flights. - **South Korea**: Korean Air has operated the 747 and A380 for international routes. - **Australia**: Qantas has used the A380 for routes like Melbourne to Los Angeles. The trend towards double-deckers has waned with a shift towards more fuel-efficient, twin-engine aircraft, but these giants still grace the skies in some parts of the world, offering that unique experience of flying in a plane that feels more like a vertical community than a traditional aircraft.

content: In 1987, cash-strapped American Airlines launched the AAirpass: $250,000 for unlimited lifetime first-class travel. Investment banker Steven Rothstein, a frequent flyer, bought one immediately. In 1989 he added a $150,000 companion pass that let anyone fly with him‚Äîeven on separate flights. From 1987 to 2008, Rothstein averaged 476 flights per year (over 10,000 total, 30 million miles). He flew to London for dinner, Tokyo for sushi, Sydney for weekends‚Äîtreating planes like buses. He used the companion pass for profound kindness: spotting stranded travelers, homeless people, priests, or refugees at airports and gifting them first-class seats home. His daughter said he turned the pass into a tool for random, life-changing generosity. American Airlines sold just 66 passes (1981‚Äì1988), raising $16.5 million. Early on, the CEO wrote Rothstein praising his use and promising to honor the deal ‚Äúfar into the future.‚Äù By 2007, facing losses, the airline created a ‚Äúrevenue integrity unit.‚Äù It calculated Rothstein and one other holder were each costing >$1 million yearly. From 2005‚Äì2008 he booked 3,000+ segments for himself (84% canceled/no-show) and 2,700 companion segments (85% unused). Many bookings used placeholder names (‚ÄúBag Rothstein,‚Äù ‚ÄúSteven Rothstein Jr.‚Äù) because he decided at the gate whom to help. Reservations were made by phone; staff knew and never objected‚Äîsome even suggested the practice. On December 13, 2008, at Chicago O‚ÄôHare, while escorting a Bosnian policeman he was flying home, Rothstein was handed a letter revoking his AAirpass for ‚Äúfraudulent usage.‚Äù His 21-year unlimited life ended instantly. The airline accused him of speculative bookings and fake names. Rothstein sued for breach of contract; AA countersued for fraud. The case settled confidentially in 2012 after AA‚Äôs bankruptcy. A deeper truth emerged in court: after his teenage son Josh died in 2002, many late-night bookings were grief-driven calls to familiar reservation agents‚Äîhis only human contact when loneliness was unbearable. The unused tickets weren‚Äôt fraud; they were a heartbroken father staying tethered to the world. American Airlines later terminated all remaining AAirpasses. Former CEO Bob Crandall admitted: ‚ÄúThe public was smarter than we were.‚Äù Rothstein never accepted wrongdoing but later said he had mixed feelings about ever buying the pass. It gave him freedom and the power to help thousands‚Äîyet ended in betrayal. His story is the last real unlimited lifetime airline pass: a brief era when a golden ticket actually meant forever, until corporate promises met bottom-line reality. For 10,000 flights and 30 million miles, Steven Rothstein lived‚Äîand shared‚Äîa dream that no longer exists.

The decided to run the fade in the airport and call it even. 94 year old homie was the only real loser here bc he was missing his business https://t.co/NKRjnrCgJM QT @KungFuRedNeck: @GangHits The fight involving rapper Jim Jones at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport began aboard an American Airlines flight from Miami on May 4, 2024, shortly after the plane landed but before it reached the gate. Jones stood up in first class to retrieve his luggage from the overhead bin, which prompted fellow passenger James Dos Santos to confront him and push him in the chest. Jones responded by grabbing Dos Santos' arm and telling him to stop, after which Dos Santos apologized. However, another passenger, Alexander Lekht (who was traveling with Dos Santos), began screaming at Jones from his seat. Airport deputies were called to the gate due to the initial confrontation, but Jones declined to file a report at that time and proceeded to baggage claim. Lekht followed Jones and continued to harass him, making sudden movements in an attempt to provoke him further. The situation escalated into a physical altercation on a nearby escalator, where Lekht swung punches at Jones, leading Jones to throw Lekht down the escalator. Dos Santos then joined in by throwing punches at Jones as well. During the brawl, a 94-year-old bystander named James Jackson was knocked to the ground and sustained minor leg injuries, requiring transport to a hospital. Jones maintained that he acted in self-defense throughout the incident, stating, "I was minding my business and defended myself. They got what they were looking for." Surveillance footage reviewed by police corroborated his account, and no charges were filed against anyone involved, as none of the parties wished to press charges.

content: It‚Äôs humbling for the low-income passengers as they‚Äôre forced to file past the pre-boarded business class passengers, on their way to the cheap seats in the back of the plane. https://t.co/qMmgeBCoQu QT @mualphaxi: Airports these days are a perfect picture of American affluenza. The US upper-ish class has too much money, but never enough. Lots of suspicious ‚Äúpre-boarders,‚Äù teens in designer clothes, $500 headphones muttering ‚Äòwhat?‚Äô to flight staff. There are like 50 people in ‚Äúboarding group 1‚Äù now, as well. You can see the confusion on people‚Äôs faces who‚Äôve clearly been boarding first for a while, who now wait 20 minutes standing just to have their spot in line! The lounges are overrun, and again, you can see the exasperation on the faces of people waiting for them, thinking they‚Äôd paid for a service and realizing that now it‚Äôs like Disneyworld. Prices across the board have gone up, and demand keeps up. This is one of the effects of mass affluence, I guess. Airline taxes are as high as ever, and as a result actual ‚Äúbudget‚Äù flights (√† la Ryanair) are not allowed. At this point, a budget flight is anything under‚Ä¶ $300? People are amazingly unforgiving. They get violent looks in their eyes when staff announce that overhead bin space will run out. For many flyers, being asked to check a bag is like being asked for one of their kidneys. So many people look at children like they‚Äôre rodents that have infiltrated the house, rather than our treasures and our future. Parents are the scapegoat of every flight. Funny enough, the TSA feels like the one thing that has gotten better. Maybe I choose my airports and flying times well, but I don‚Äôt remember the last time I waited more than 15 minutes to get through. Sometimes the CLEAR line is comically longer than the regular line next to it. And for whatever reason, people will just _not_ move over to the shorter line. It‚Äôs pretty rare to see actual brawling, but you do hear about these things. As a writer and chronicler of America, this entropy interests me. I‚Äôm almost immunized from feeling the pressure, because I‚Äôve taught myself to laugh about it and observe. I see the story, and as a result the chaos isn‚Äôt so bad. And to me, mass affluence is the biggest story in the country. People who thought they‚Äôd ‚Äúmade it‚Äù are stuck in a Commons that they feel has degraded. They‚Äôre in a race to constant fly all around the country, and even the ones with quite a bit of money are feeling the squeeze. At the Santa Barbara airport recently, about to board an upsetting expensive, 38 minute flight to San Francisco, I saw this in its purest form. Everyone flying from SB to SF is ‚Äúrich.‚Äù Nearly all live in multimillion-dollar houses. And there they were, watching private jets take off through the windows, about to board a full commercial flight themselves. Affluenza. Me? I try to always feel the wonder. Isn‚Äôt it amazing how quickly we can get basically anywhere? It seems so soul destroying to develop an entitlement here. The US is what it is. And it‚Äôs a machine to make services widely available at a market price. The chaos begins when a lot more people get pretty wealthy; you see this same pattern in ski resorts, housing markets, etc. Already we see lots of cultural messaging encouraging people to ‚Äúexit‚Äù from all this ‚Äî either by amassing enough money, or by voluntarily choosing slower things (trains, small towns, camping). I think we‚Äôll see more of that. What do you think of my theory?

content: @Buma11252252 @esjesjesj @LouiseRawAuthor Yes, that's a genuine historical photo of Air France's first-class meal service aboard a Boeing 747 in 1988. It depicts the elaborate, white-glove dining typical of premium cabins back then, with uniformed attendants serving multi-course meals at individual tables. Such opulence has largely faded due to cost pressures and evolving airline economics, not just cultural shifts.

content: I've flown international business class with most of the major airlines this year. Here's my ranking 1. Qatar - Everything feels like flying first class - For Ex. How do they keep a filet perfectly medium rare for that long (sous vide is the only explination I have). But please, this movie selection is horrendous. And loungewear for long haul flights is nice. @qatarairways 2. Emirates - Excellent food and beverage, great service, entertainment selection is great. They make you feel special and bed is very comfortable. @emirates 3. Turkish - Good - I like the black color motif, food and service are good, spacious cabin. @TurkishAirlines 4. United - Decent overall but Polaris is incredibly cramped. Food and beverage is good, but not excellent. Entertainment is great with big list of Hollywood films. @united 5. Air France, British and Lufthansa are all just ok 6. Ethiopian - honrable mention because I like injera. Other business class I've flown is basically a step up from premium economy. Royal Air Maroc, Singapore, Royal Brunei Airlines, Thai Airways International, and many other country specific airlines. I've flown ALOT this year, and while I don't enjoy the 14+ hr flights, I've just decided to enjoy the small details that make it less miserable. #travel #airlines

content: Make him famous for this TOO Great guy https://t.co/VjnmOVqp4v QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I can‚Äôt help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say it‚Äôs just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesn‚Äôt know I‚Äôm back. They tell me that I‚Äôm going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. I‚Äôm pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, ‚ÄúHow much is it?‚Äù They tell him $50 and he says ‚ÄúI got it.‚Äù I‚Äôm astonished and tell him it‚Äôs fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this man‚Äôs generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. I‚Äôm crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as he‚Äôs sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. Be that person for someone because I know after this I sure will be." üíï Update: It was NFL player, Jermaine Gresham." Credit: Deliliah Cassidy (2018)

content: # Lufthansa-Notfall: iPad im Sitz f√ºhrt zu Flugumkehr üî•‚úàÔ∏è *@charter_97* üì±üõ¨ ## Technologie und Flugrisiken: Wenn Alltagsger√§te zur Gefahr werden In einer bemerkenswerten Wendung der Ereignisse musste k√ºrzlich ein Lufthansa-Flug von Los Angeles nach M√ºnchen umkehren, nachdem das iPad eines Business-Class-Passagiers in seinem Sitz eingeklemmt wurde. Der Vorfall wirft wichtige Fragen zur Sicherheit elektronischer Ger√§te an Bord von Flugzeugen auf. #Flugsicherheit #TechRisiken Der Airbus mit 461 Personen an Bord befand sich bereits seit drei Stunden im Luftraum, als die Besatzung die schwerwiegende Entscheidung traf, nach Los Angeles zur√ºckzukehren. Trotz mehrerer Versuche gelang es der Crew nicht, das Ger√§t zu befreien, was zu wachsenden Bedenken hinsichtlich einer m√∂glichen Brandgefahr f√ºhrte. üö® ### Experten warnen vor versteckten Gefahren üßê "Eingeklemmte Lithium-Ionen-Batterien stellen ein erhebliches Sicherheitsrisiko dar," erkl√§rt Prof. Dr. Klaus Weber, Experte f√ºr Luftfahrtsicherheit an der TU M√ºnchen. "Bei Verformung k√∂nnen diese Batterien √ºberhitzen und in Brand geraten ‚Äì ein Szenario, das auf 10.000 Meter H√∂he absolut vermieden werden muss." #Batteriesicherheit Die International Air Transport Association (IATA) hat in den letzten Jahren wiederholt auf die Gefahren aufmerksam gemacht, die von elektronischen Ger√§ten ausgehen k√∂nnen. "Es ist nicht das erste Mal, dass ein eingeklemmtes Ger√§t einen Notfall verursacht," bemerkt Luftfahrtanalystin Sabine Hoffmann. "2019 musste ein Virgin Atlantic Flug √§hnlich umkehren, nachdem ein Smartphone in einem Sitz einen Brandgeruch verursacht hatte." üìä ### Konsequenzen f√ºr Passagiere und Fluggesellschaft üíº F√ºr die betroffenen Reisenden bedeutete dieser Vorfall eine erhebliche Verz√∂gerung ihrer Reisepl√§ne. Lufthansa organisierte Ersatzfl√ºge und Unterk√ºnfte, doch der finanzielle und logistische Aufwand war betr√§chtlich. "Solche Vorf√§lle kosten Fluggesellschaften durchschnittlich zwischen 100.000 und 200.000 Euro," sch√§tzt Wirtschaftsexperte Dr. Thomas Reichart. "Neben den direkten Kosten f√ºr Treibstoff und Unterbringung kommt es zu Folgeverschiebungen im gesamten Flugplan." #Wirtschaftsfaktor ### Verhaltensempfehlungen f√ºr Reisende üìù Um √§hnliche Vorf√§lle zu vermeiden, empfehlen Experten: - Elektronische Ger√§te w√§hrend der Sitzverstellung im Blick behalten üëÄ - Bei Verlust eines Ger√§ts sofort das Kabinenpersonal informieren ‚úã - Auf stark besch√§digte Ger√§te an Bord verzichten üö´ - Powerbanks und Ersatzbatterien nur im Handgep√§ck transportieren üß≥ ### Zukunftsperspektiven: Sitzdesign und Technik üîÆ Flugzeughersteller arbeiten bereits an verbesserten Sitzdesigns, die solche Vorf√§lle vermeiden sollen. "Wir entwickeln Sitzmechanismen, die elektronische Ger√§te erkennen und den Verstellmechanismus automatisch stoppen," erkl√§rt Ingenieurin Marlene Koster von einem f√ºhrenden Flugzeugsitzhersteller. "Sicherheit muss mit dem digitalen Zeitalter Schritt halten." #Innovation Bis diese neuen Technologien fl√§chendeckend eingesetzt werden, bleibt Vorsicht das oberste Gebot. Wie der Lufthansa-Vorfall zeigt, k√∂nnen selbst allt√§gliche Ger√§te unter bestimmten Umst√§nden zu ernsthaften Sicherheitsrisiken werden. ### Fazit: Bewusstsein schafft Sicherheit üí≠ Der Vorfall unterstreicht die Notwendigkeit eines bewussteren Umgangs mit Elektronik an Bord. "Passagiere sollten ihre Ger√§te stets im Blick behalten und vorsichtig mit der Sitzverstellung umgehen," r√§t Kabinenchef Martin Berger. "Im Zweifel immer die Crew informieren ‚Äì besser einmal zu viel als zu wenig." #Sicherheitstipps --- *Dieser Artikel basiert auf verf√ºgbaren Informationen zum Lufthansa-Vorfall. content: I've flown international business class with most of the major airlines this year. Here's my ranking 1. Qatar - Everything feels like flying first class - For Ex. How do they keep a filet perfectly medium rare for that long (sous vide is the only explination I have). But please, this movie selection is horrendous. And loungewear for long haul flights is nice. @qatarairways 2. Emirates - Excellent food and beverage, great service, entertainment selection is great. They make you feel special and bed is very comfortable. @emirates 3. Turkish - Good - I like the black color motif, food and service are good, spacious cabin. @TurkishAirlines 4. United - Decent overall but Polaris is incredibly cramped. Food and beverage is good, but not excellent. Entertainment is great with big list of Hollywood films. @united 5. Air France, British and Lufthansa are all just ok 6. Ethiopian - honrable mention because I like injera. Other business class I've flown is basically a step up from premium economy. Royal Air Maroc, Singapore, Royal Brunei Airlines, Thai Airways International, and many other country specific airlines. I've flown ALOT this year, and while I don't enjoy the 14+ hr flights, I've just decided to enjoy the small details that make it less miserable. #travel #airlinesThey

content: L‚Äôhomme qui a transform√© un billet d‚Äôavion en cl√© du monde En 1987, Steven Rothstein, un homme d‚Äôaffaires de l‚ÄôIllinois, a pos√© un geste qui allait le faire entrer dans la l√©gende du voyage. Pour la somme colossale de 250 000 dollars, il a acquis l‚ÄôAAirpass d‚ÄôAmerican Airlines, un s√©same promettant des vols illimit√©s √† vie, en premi√®re classe, vers n‚Äôimporte quelle destination de la plan√®te. Ce n‚Äô√©tait pas seulement un achat, c‚Äô√©tait l‚Äôacquisition d‚Äôune libert√© sans fronti√®res. Pendant plus de deux d√©cennies, Rothstein a men√© une existence hors du commun, affranchie des contraintes de temps et de distance. Son quotidien se d√©roulait entre les fuseaux horaires : un petit-d√©jeuner √† New York, un d√©jeuner d‚Äôaffaires √† Londres, et un coucher de soleil √† Tokyo. On estime qu‚Äôil a effectu√© plus de 10 000 vols, accumulant des dizaines de millions de miles, et co√ªtant √† la compagnie a√©rienne une somme estim√©e √† plus de 21 millions de dollars. Mais au-del√† de l‚Äôexploit logistique et du luxe, Rothstein voyait dans cet abonnement une v√©ritable philosophie de vie. Il voyageait parfois sans but pr√©cis, simplement pour le plaisir de voler. Mieux encore, il utilisait son privil√®ge pour inviter des inconnus rencontr√©s dans les a√©roports √† l‚Äôaccompagner en premi√®re classe, transformant son voyage en un acte de g√©n√©rosit√© spontan√©e. Il vivait avec la l√©g√®ret√© d‚Äôun oiseau, faisant du monde son voisinage. Cette utopie a pris fin brutalement en 2008. American Airlines, r√©alisant l‚Äô√©normit√© de la perte financi√®re engendr√©e par ces pass illimit√©s, a cherch√© une porte de sortie. La compagnie a finalement annul√© le pass de Rothstein, l‚Äôaccusant d‚Äôen avoir ‚Äútrop profit√©‚Äù et de pratiques frauduleuses, notamment l‚Äôutilisation de faux noms pour r√©server des si√®ges de compagnon. Bien que la justice ait finalement donn√© raison √† la compagnie en 2011, l‚Äôhistoire de Steven Rothstein demeure un t√©moignage fascinant. Il reste l‚Äôhomme qui a prouv√© qu‚Äôil √©tait possible, pour un temps, de faire du ciel sa v√©ritable adresse, et dont la l√©gende continue de voler bien au-del√† de l‚Äôannulation de son billet. content: @ClassicsPlanes "Lockheed L-1011 TriStar. Usually spoken of in its homeland the US as either the ‚ÄúL-One-Oh-Eleven‚Äù or the ‚ÄúL-Ten-Eleven,‚Äù which was parodied in its declining years as L-Ten-a-Lemon and said to denote Late 10 out of 11 times; also the Tribastard and Frightstar. Swamp Buggy and Swamp Eater referred to the infamous Eastern 401 crash in the Everglades in 1972. Eastern included the TriStar in their Whisperliner fleet, and when introduced on Caribbean routes it was referred to there as el Grandote (The Big Guy) At PSA the widebody was the Mother Grinning Bird to complement the narrowbody Grinning Birds. Cabin crew at Delta called it the Tritanic, as a slight nose-up attitude in flight was thought reminiscent of the raised bow of a sinking ship. When first introduced into British Airways service, pilots called it the Tripod, and cabin crew allegedly knew it as the Big Dipper because of the increased opportunities for ‚ÄúDipping‚Äù (transferring free First-Class spirits into miniatures for private re-sale in Economy) The ‚ÄúSunset‚Äù mod at BA involved replacing the lower galley and lifts on -200s to create extra freight space. The unusual semi-circle of toilets at the rear was known within Lockheed as Cannery Row (can being US slang for a toilet) and at Caledonian as Penny Lane (‚ÄúSpending a penny‚Äù being British slang for using a toilet) The aforementioned nose-up pitch combined with urine splashes was said to produce a distinctly unpleasant smell on the TriStar, and if the lids were up and thrust-reversal applied on landing the resultant sound was said to be like ‚Äúgunfire.‚Äù The noise-reducing fairing below the intake of the centre engine on the -500 was known as the Frisbee, not because of any resemblance to the throwing disc but because it was devised by Lockheed‚Äôs Lloyd Frisbee. BiStar was a reference to engine failures, although it was also used more formally in relation to the unbuilt twin-engined L-1011-600 (aka the CL1600) The only military operator was the UK, who bought 6 ex British Airways L1011-500s in the immediate wake of the 1982 Falklands war, primarily for use as K.1 & KC.1 tankers; these soon became known as Tommies, possibly deriving from the rhyming slang Tommy Tanker (Wanker) A further 3 ex Pan Am -500s were ordered 2 years later as pure C.2 passenger aircraft and given the complementary name of Timmy, with the sole C.2A upgrade sometimes being referred to as Tammy. The two TriStars sent to Saudi Arabia during the first Gulf War and given ‚Äùsand pink‚Äù camouflage were known collectively as the Pink Pigs or Flying Pigs, and individually as Pinky & Perky after the children‚Äôs TV show characters. British charter operator Court Line also had a pink TriStar, G-BAAB ‚ÄúHalcyon Breeze‚Äù known within the company as the Pink Lady, operated alongside G-BAAA ‚ÄúHalcyon Days‚Äù or the Big Banana." This, and thousands more aviation nicknames, colloquialisms, changed names, airline class names, fictional names, anecdotes & fun facts, lesser-known conversions, upgrades & variant names, reporting names and naming protocols all recorded and analysed here - https://t.co/D9RExxigac

content: Numbers don‚Äôt lie, and the poor business decisions here are undeniable. It‚Äôs hard to see how any company could justify these results. Ultimately, the impacts are clear. The company‚Äôs reputation has been damaged, and the fans have borne the burden. Ticket prices were raised, yet the outcome was deeply disappointing. Fans experienced disorganization, last-minute benefit cancellations, and even disrespect toward the thoughtful gifts they prepared. These are loyal supporters who waited years to meet the girls, only to have their love tarnished and treated carelessly by the organizers. IDF should take the time to truly digest fans' feedback and reflect. Even if they are not directly responsible for the organizer‚Äôs behaviour, as the client they should have a say in how these issues are handled moving forward. Adding to this is the unfair treatment toward our girls. Visibility matters, yet while international and local media highlighted the tremendous success of the tour and the passionate support of fans, the company itself remained silent on its own social media channels. When your own artists achieve such milestones, acknowledgment should be the minimum. @coldenvy @Karanx_ My five cents. You underestimate just how much the structure of society shapes human behavior. Without institutions, without enforced norms, there‚Äôs only a fragile barrier separating civilization from the chaos of history. We get glimpses of this in war, riots, and moments of lawlessness‚Äîbut for the most part, societal structure keeps people in line, adhering to an unspoken social contract. Occasionally, though, we see cracks in that structure‚Äîreminders of how thin the veil really is. My brother once told me a story about watching Brazilians check in for a flight to the United States. The scene was loud and chaotic‚Äîshouting, jostling, cutting in line‚Äîbecause in that environment, securing attention and getting what you need requires forcefulness. In a society where institutions are weaker, you have to act in your own interest because everyone else does. To someone from a highly structured society, this behavior seems aggressive, even rude. But within that system, it‚Äôs simply survival. Then, something remarkable happened. The same people, upon entering the first-class lounge of American Airlines in S√£o Paulo, transformed instantly. Gone was the shouting, the shoving, the disorder. Inside the lounge, they adapted to the rules of a structured environment‚Äîa space governed by the quiet, orderly expectations of American or Canadian norms. The contrast was stark. This is why institutions matter. They don‚Äôt just impose order; they shape behavior itself. When people talk about dismantling these structures, they should tread carefully. Because when the scaffolding of society weakens, history reminds us of what waits on the other side.

content: I made the mistake of leaving four hours between a Madrid to Heathrow and Heathrow to Atlanta business class flight. Had to change terminal from 5 to 3. From leaving the arriving plane at 5 to sitting down in the Cathay Pacific lounge with champagne took 30 minutes üòÇ https://t.co/WnPZunKD7a QT @Noahpinion: Today, I made the mistake of flying from Dublin to Paris via London's Heathrow Airport. This was a remarkably stupid move on my part, given that London, and by extension Heathrow, is located in the failing formerly-developed country known as "the UK". I almost paid dearly for this oversight. My layover was 1 hour and 30 minutes. As soon as my flight from Dublin arrived at Terminal 2, I began looking around for my connecting flight to Paris, which was located in Terminal 5. A helpful immigration officer pointed me in the direction of a free train that I could take to Terminal 5. After walking for about 15 minutes through a labyrinthine maze of tunnels, I arrived at this train. The train required me to get a ticket for the free trip to Terminal 5. After standing in line at a machine, I pressed a button that dispensed this ticket. I then used the ticket to go through a turnstyle. Once on the platform (which was poorly labeled), I discovered -- by asking some locals -+ that the trains for Terminal 4 do not actually go to Terminal 5. (This had not been apparent from any signs or other information in the train station.) I would thus have to wait 17 minutes for the dedicated train to Terminal 5. And so wait I did. About 20 minutes later I arrived at Terminal 5, and discovered that I was in the Departures area. Despite the fact that I was transferring, I would have to go through airport security again. So I waited in line for security, watching other people struggle with the automated boarding pass scanners. Finally I reached the scanners, and when I scanned my boarding pass, it registered an error, and told me to see a British Airways employee. (Sadly, my Aer Lingus flight was operated by British Airways.) So I went to the British Airways departures counter, and after a while I found the line I was supposed to stand in. I waited 10 minutes in the line, and was finally allowed to see a British Airways employee. The British Airways employee informed me that I had already missed my flight, since boarding was at 12:15 and it was now 12:17. I argued that boarding would probably last more than two minutes, and that I might still have time to make the flight, whose departure was scheduled for 12:55. She seemed skeptical of this argument, but I finally persuaded her to help me give it a try. Returning me to the security line, the British Airways woman told me to wait in the line (which would have taken 15 minutes). I begged her to let me jump the queue, and she did, explaining my plight to a South Asian security employee who let me through the rope barrier to the front of the line. This South Asian man is actually the hero of our story. When I cut to the front of the security line, a security employee barked at me to get back. The lovely South Asian man then barked at her to let me through, and his confident air of command carried the day. I was let through, and the South Asian man even showed me how to use the security machine so that it would definitely not stop me from entering. He told me to tell his colleagues at the baggage scanner that I was allowed to jump to the front of the queue. I raced to the baggage scanning line, which looked like it would have taken an additional 20 minutes, and simply ducked under the barriers and cut to the front of the line. I apologized to the employee there and told him my flight was already boarding. He told me that in that case, I had already missed my flight, and it wasn't even worth continuing. But I told him that his colleague (the aforementioned South Asian man) had instructed me to go through security anyway, and he accepted this and let me through. I had to do an extra scan of my shoes, but made it through OK. I then ran to my gate, ducking and weaving around various travelers. content: @AnitaAnandMP Air Canada‚Äôs new rule about not allowing carry-ons for those who buy economy or ‚Äúbasic fare‚Äù tickets really shows how much the wealthy are prioritized. I‚Äôve flown both first class & economy, and the difference is unbelievable. When I fly economy, I‚Äôm standing at check-in, desperately shifting 3 to 4 pounds in my luggage just to avoid paying extra fees. But when you‚Äôre flying first class, you get an extra suitcase AND 20 more pounds per bag‚Äîno hassle. It‚Äôs clear: if you‚Äôve got the money, you get treated way better. This new policy just adds to the divide. It‚Äôs hard to buy into the idea that ‚Äúall humans are equal‚Äù when it‚Äôs obvious that the more you pay, the better your experience is.

content: Hello! This is effectively part zero of a nine part series I will be writing over the coming days about how I am going to gain British Airways Gold Status. I will share everything about the booking process, the flights, airports, cost, and whether I think it‚Äôs actually worth it. If you prefer video, I will be sharing updates & reviews over on the Smart With Points TikTok, Instagram & YouTube Kicking Things Off It is important to note that I will be starting from 40 tier points. These were primarily earned through two return journeys in economy with British Airways. I flew from London Heathrow to Manchester for one, and London Gatwick to Jersey for the other. These were my four qualifying flights which are required to progress from Bronze to Silver/Gold. I earned a further 10 tier points from a return economy trip prior with Malaysian Airlines. This was taken before I even thought about attempting a tier point run and yielded a poor TP per ¬£. The Tier Point Run For my tier point run, I'll be embarking on a journey across multiple countries, flying with SriLankan Airlines and Cathay Pacific in business class. The trip kicks off with a flight from Abu Dhabi (AUH) to Colombo (CMB), where I'll have my first layover. From there, I'll head to Jakarta (CGK) and back to Colombo again, with a brief stop before returning to Abu Dhabi. This segment will be crucial for earning a good chunk of tier points as I transit multiple times through Colombo without actually stopping for a long visit. Colombo is situated just over 2000 miles between Abu Dhabi and Jakarta, making it the perfect route to earn tier points. After that, I'll fly from Abu Dhabi to Colombo and Jakarta once again, and then connect with Cathay Pacific to Hong Kong (HKG). From Hong Kong, I'll take a short hop to Taipei (TPE) and back, purely transiting through these cities. I'll then make my way back to Jakarta and switch back to SriLankan Airlines to complete the final legs of my trip, flying from Jakarta to Colombo and ending the run back in Abu Dhabi. Throughout the journey, I'll be stopping briefly in Jakarta and Taipei while purely transiting through places like Hong Kong and Colombo, all in pursuit of maximising my Avios and collecting a total of 1,480 tier points. Last Minute Changes Originally, I was due to fly AUH to CGK and back three times. Although this route earns the most tier points (560 TP x 3), I don‚Äôt actually need that many for Gold. It would also mean the whole process would take a day longer, due to the SriLankan only flying 5 days a week to Jakarta. Adding the Cathay Pacific flights in there gets me just the right number of tier points whilst making it more enjoyable trip. Shout out to Matts Planet for the route idea. More over at @SmartWithPoints

content: Hello again! Happy Monday. Welcome to the third instalment of my British Airways Gold status adventure. Today, we're covering my journey from Abu Dhabi (AUH) to Jakarta (CGK) via Colombo (CMB). Buckle up for another rollercoaster ride of near-misses, unexpected luxuries, and the ongoing saga of e-visa complications! AUH to CMB: A Comedy of Errors (Almost) Having become somewhat of an AUH expert by now, I decided to cut it fine with my airport arrival. The Pearl Lounge, while nice, isn't exactly the height of luxury (no free cocktails or bubbly - the horror!), so I wasn't too fussed about maximising my time there. However, my nonchalance almost backfired. I'm sitting at gate 15, waiting patiently, when I spot on the board that my flight is boarding... at a completely different gate! Cue a mad dash across the terminal. I made it, but only just, earning myself the title of "Last to Board." Pro tip: Always double-check your gate! The silver lining? The plane was practically empty - only about 30 passengers total, with a mere 4 of us living it up in business class. Flight Details: ‚Ä¢ Dinner: A delightful mutton stew ‚Ä¢ Beverages: Baileys, and my now-signature peppermint tea ‚Ä¢ Sleep Quality: Excellent, thanks to familiarity with the seat setup We landed in Colombo a bit early, only to be met with a bus gate. But here's where things got interesting: they shuttled all four of us business class passengers to the terminal separately! I wasn‚Äôt expecting that. Colombo Layover: The Quest for Quiet This time in Colombo, I struck gold in the SriLankan Airlines lounge. I discovered a quiet room with some seriously comfy reclining sofas. For two blissful hours, I stretched out in peace, recharging for the next leg of my journey. Once again, the lounge staff's timing was impeccable. They announced our boarding just in time for us to stroll directly onto the plane. No crowded gate lounges for us! CMB to CGK: Sleep is the New Breakfast The flight to Jakarta was considerably busier, but the travel gods smiled upon me once more - I had an open seat next to me. This time, I made the executive decision to skip breakfast in favour of more sleep (and, of course, another peppermint tea). It was definitely the right call; I felt remarkably refreshed upon arrival. Jakarta: The E-Gate Saga Continues Remember my e-gate troubles from last time? Well, they're back with a vengeance. After three failed attempts, I found myself in the unenviable position of queuing for 30 minutes at immigration. The plot thickens: The passport officer informed me that having two visas at the same time is a no-no - apparently, one activates and one cancels. However, he stamped my passport anyway, and I received an email confirming my second visa was activated. The mystery deepens! Hotel Adventures and Future Complications For this stay, I switched things up and tried a different hotel in the hope of getting more sleep. Getting there was an adventure in itself - I narrowly missed the free shuttle and decided to live on the edge by taking a Grab motorbike. Not only was it faster, but it was also way more fun! Now, here's where things get a bit tricky. I'm trying to check in for my upcoming Cathay Pacific flights to Taipei, but the online system is demanding my new Indonesian visa details. The catch? I can't apply for a new e-visa until I exit Indonesia tomorrow. It looks like I'll be heading to the airport tomorrow, fingers crossed, hoping they can check me in for the Taipei flight without these details. Looking Ahead As I sit here in my hotel room having just eaten a Nasi Goreng, contemplating the visa issue that awaits me, I can't help but feel a mix of excitement and trepidation. Will I make it to Taipei without a hitch? Will the e-gates ever accept me? And most importantly, will I ever tire of peppermint tea? Stay tuned for the next instalment of this tier point odyssey. If nothing else, it promises to be... interesting! Until next time, may your connections be smooth and your e-gates cooperative!
