content: I'm smiling cos I was going to help my wantok at the airport as he had reached his card's ceiling, but when I heard the amount he was trying to withdraw, I said, sorry, not today. üòÑ Mi sori lo hem be ino pei dei yet. https://t.co/BdUa36xBpq QT @fopminui: "WOW okay so the most amazing thing just happened to me and I can‚Äôt help but share it with the world. American Airlines instituted a new policy where you have to pay to take a carry-on onto the plane. Which is ridiculous but off topic. I consolidate my bags into one and they measure it and say it‚Äôs just a little too big. They proceed to charge me $50, except they only take credit card, no cash. Since I just got back from Europe all my cards are being declined as Chase doesn‚Äôt know I‚Äôm back. They tell me that I‚Äôm going to have to miss the flight and head back to the ticket counter to pay down there. I‚Äôm pleading, devastated after a long day of travel. Then, this man walks up and says, ‚ÄúHow much is it?‚Äù They tell him $50 and he says ‚ÄúI got it.‚Äù I‚Äôm astonished and tell him it‚Äôs fine not to worry and he hands the lady his card as the American Airlines employees stand in silence shocked by this man‚Äôs generosity. They swipe the card and he tells me to have a great flight and hop on board. I‚Äôm crying as I write this and as I board the flight. This man was an angel. I stop him as he‚Äôs sitting in first class and try to give him my money but he just shook me off and told me to pay it forward. My heart is so happy. There are good people in this world. content: Emirates is doing exactly what I predicted. Miles and points have flooded the system, eroding the exclusivity of luxury travel. Other airlines, Qatar, Singapore, BA, Lufthansa, have all quietly cut perks on reward seats. Emirates took it further: no chauffeur, no lounge, no baggage, and now bans on children in first class, with business likely next. The message is clear: if you‚Äôre not paying cash, you‚Äôre not a priority or are you the customer they want in their premium cabins. Airlines don‚Äôt profit from your points flights, so they‚Äôre taking back control. If, like me, you‚Äôre sitting on 500k+ points, you need to get strategic. My go-to is the hybrid cash + points strategy, using points to offset the cash cost of premium cabins while keeping all the perks. It stretches points further and still gives you the full luxury experience without breaking the bank.

content: Hi there - I would like to complain about an experience I am currently having on flight 2184 CLT-SFO. I‚Äôve flown this route dozens of times for work in the past year, mostly in first class but sometimes in economy as well. I am in seat 10A today, a window seat. There is a non-rev American Airlines captain in the middle seat and another larger passenger in the aisle seat who probably should have purchased two seats All of a sudden, the captain in the middle seat gruffly tells me that the armrest is for use only by the middle seat, and that he should have access to both arm rests. I politely respond that I‚Äôm only occupying my seat and ask why he‚Äôs being so rude. He responds ‚Äúbecause I‚Äôm dealing with this situation (pointing to the overweight passenger in the aisle seat) and you‚Äôre fucking pushing into my arm‚Äù to which I responded politely: I‚Äôm staying in my seat. The captain then responds ‚ÄúI can get a flight attendant and I promise you they‚Äôll take my side‚Äù to which I responded ‚Äúprobably so, since you‚Äôre crew‚Äù and he said ‚ÄúI‚Äôm the captain?‚Äù Question- is this acceptable behavior from an American Airlines captain non-revving? This captain is still sitting next to me in 10B and frankly I‚Äôm afraid to say anything else because of his threats to get the flight attendants involved and how ‚Äúthey will take his side‚Äù. Use of the F word and cursing as well is unbecoming of an airline captain. I‚Äôm not sure how to proceed but I am planning to write a letter to Robert Issom as well. I am hoping the captain is just having a bad day and it‚Äôs not of a reflection of who he truly is, because I would be afraid to fly on a plane he is flying in the mood that he is in at the moment.

W√§hrend sie mit entr√ºcktem Blick und dramatischen Worten die Apokalypse verk√ºndet, marschiert ihre Gefolgschaft in Richtung wirtschaftlicher Selbstzerst√∂rung ‚Äì und klatscht dabei begeistert. Fliegen, Feiern, Fordern ‚Äì Klima-Aktivismus auf First-Class-Niveau Einer ihrer bekanntesten ‚ÄûAusrutscher‚Äú war die Diskussion um ihre eigenen Flugreisen. W√§hrend sie anderen vorschreibt, dass Fliegen b√∂se ist, jettete sie selbst fr√∂hlich durch die Weltgeschichte. Ihre Antwort? ‚ÄûIch hatte ja keine Wahl.‚Äú Genau. Weil es ja auch keine Z√ºge gibt. Oder Videokonferenzen. Oder einen Funken Konsequenz in ihren eigenen Forderungen. Neubauer lebt in einem Widerspruchskosmos, in dem f√ºr sie selbst andere Regeln gelten als f√ºr die ‚Äûdummen Massen‚Äú. W√§hrend sie sich an Kohlekraftwerken festklebt, um ‚Äûdie Zukunft zu retten‚Äú, m√ºssen normale B√ºrger schauen, wie sie mit explodierenden Energiepreisen klarkommen. W√§hrend sie den Untergang der Welt predigt, macht sie sich ihre eigene Zukunft goldgr√ºn: Buchvertr√§ge, Medienauftritte, Lobbytreffen ‚Äì ein Aktivismus, der vor allem einem Zweck dient: ihrer eigenen Karriere. Das Fazit: Klima-Heilige oder clevere Gesch√§ftsfrau? Luisa Neubauer ist kein Umweltengel. Sie ist eine perfekt inszenierte PR-Maschine. Ihre Kampagne hat mit echter Wissenschaft oder nachhaltiger Politik so viel zu tun wie ein Tesla mit Umweltschutz ‚Äì klingt gut, sieht gut aus, ist aber am Ende doch nur Marketing. Die Frage ist: Wie lange lassen sich die Leute noch t√§uschen? Solange die Kameras blitzen und die Medien sie als ‚Äûletzte Hoffnung des Planeten‚Äú verkaufen, wird Luisa Neubauer weiter ihre Show abziehen. Doch irgendwann ‚Äì wenn selbst ihre eigenen J√ºnger merken, dass sie nichts weiter als ein gr√ºnes Hochglanzprodukt ist ‚Äì k√∂nnte ihr Stern genauso schnell vergl√ºhen, wie sie ihn selbst angez√ºndet hat. content: $DAL Delta Air Lines reported a stronger-than-expected profit for the last three months of 2024 and predicted even better earnings for the start of 2025. The company said demand for premium travel, like first-class and business-class seats, has been growing quickly as more people are willing to pay for extra comfort. This helped Delta‚Äôs ticket sales increase faster than expected, and its shares reached a record high. The airline also explained that fewer available seats on flights have led to higher ticket prices, which has boosted its earnings. Delta‚Äôs CEO, Ed Bastian, said the airline industry is getting stronger financially and expects this positive trend to continue. Delta believes 2025 will be a record-breaking year for profits, thanks to higher prices and strong demand for travel. The company said travelers are still willing to pay for tickets, even with prices rising, and a strong U.S. dollar is making international trips cheaper for Americans. Delta also expects flights between the U.S. and Europe to bring in a lot of money this year. Even though recent wildfires in Los Angeles slightly hurt sales, they aren‚Äôt expected to impact Delta‚Äôs overall performance. With earnings predicted to be higher than ever, analysts are calling Delta‚Äôs future outlook very promising.

content: I was super elite with air canada for 6 years. I flew for comfort because when i landed I was expected to be on. Execution > Posing https://t.co/XnzcSkQUU1 QT @kylematthewsceo: Business tip; Whenever you are flying commercial, especially in business/first class, always wear your best business suit & tie combo (business formal). When someone walks on the plane in a great suit, white dress shirt & clean tie, I always think to myself, ‚ÄúI wonder what that guy/gal does for a living.‚Äù (Obviously no tie for the ladies ;)) It‚Äôs human nature. When I was 22, and now that I am 42, I always find myself wanting ask him/her ‚Äúhey, what do you do for a living?‚Äù If you are in commercial real estate, especially brokerage, by dressing your absolute professional best, people will ask you ‚Äúwhat do you do for a living?‚Äù, and that‚Äôs all you need to get the conversation started. In business/first class, there is a real chance they are in the real estate business, but an even better chance they know someone in the real estate industry, someone who can be your client one day. It is an easy way to network and meet new people, you just have to give a little more effort to dress up and eschew your ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt give a sh*t‚Äù sweat pants and F-U hoodie. This also works in coach, just to a lesser degree. Combine the professional clothes with a clean shave, combed hair, and I hate to admit, yes a nice watch helps, at minimum you will get looks, and in all likelihood the person sitting next to you will have to ask‚Ä¶ ‚Äúhey, what do you do for a living?‚Äù

content: $DAL Delta Air Lines had a better start to the year than many people expected, even though fewer people are taking trips for fun within the U.S. High prices and lower confidence in the economy made some travelers, especially those who look for the cheapest seats, decide not to fly as much. This caused a 5% drop in domestic travel demand. Because of that, Delta is being careful and doesn‚Äôt plan to add more flights later this year like they originally thought. But not all parts of the business are struggling‚ÄîDelta made more money from people buying first-class or premium tickets, and their loyalty program with American Express brought in a record $2 billion. Delta is also doing well in international travel, which makes up about 40% of their business. Places like the Pacific region saw a 16% jump in travel demand, helping balance out the slower domestic market. Even though Delta is unsure about the rest of 2025, especially with the new tariffs causing problems for global trade, they still expect decent results in the second quarter. Lower fuel prices are also helping the airline save money. It looks like this year will be tough for airlines, but Delta‚Äôs mix of premium, international, and loyalty program income may help it do better than others.

content: @DefiantLs Here are The Facts so you don‚Äôt have to waste your time: American Airlines Flight Attendant Pleads Guilty to Recording Underage Girls in Airplane Bathrooms, Faces Up to 20 Years Estes Carter Thompson III January 2024 Lynchburg, Virginia Facts of the Case: Estes Carter Thompson III, a 37-year-old former American Airlines flight attendant from Charlotte, North Carolina, was involved in a disturbing incident on September 2, 2023, aboard American Airlines Flight 1441 from Charlotte Douglas International Airport to Boston Logan International Airport. While working as a flight attendant, Thompson escorted a 14-year-old girl to the first-class lavatory after she found the main cabin restroom occupied. He entered the bathroom beforehand, claiming he needed to wash his hands. The girl discovered an iPhone taped to the underside of the toilet seat lid with red stickers, which Thompson had placed to secretly record her. She took photos of the setup and reported it to her parents, who alerted the crew. The captain then notified law enforcement. Upon landing in Boston, authorities investigated and arrested Thompson later in January 2024 in Lynchburg, Virginia. A search of Thompson‚Äôs iCloud account revealed recordings of four additional underage girls (aged 7, 9, 11, and 14) using airplane restrooms on previous flights, along with hundreds of AI-generated sexually explicit images of children and a photo of a 9-year-old unaccompanied minor asleep in her seat. Thompson admitted to using the hidden iPhone to record the girls and collecting a massive trove of child pornography. Outcome: On March 6, 2025, Thompson pleaded guilty in federal court to two counts of sexual exploitation of children and attempt, as well as possession of child pornography and attempt. He faces up to 20 years in prison for the child exploitation charges, with sentencing scheduled for June 2025. The exact sentence has not yet been determined as of March 8, 2025.

content: Yes it‚Äôs satirical but that‚Äôs the thing with satire, it pokes fun at the truth. There are a great many people just as insane as portrayed here. https://t.co/jviaHephIS QT @EUAITaxonomy: I read the news this morning. Lufthansa has signed a deal with Elon Musk‚Äôs Starlink to equip 850 aircraft with high-speed internet. The politicians are furious. I am furious. I immediately booked a flight to Frankfurt to protest at the First Class Terminal (I have Senator status, obviously). "This is a betrayal of Digital Sovereignty," I told the lounge attendant. "You are routing the data of honest European passengers through American satellites owned by a man who does not respect the Digital Services Act." "But Lars," she said. "Starlink offers 150 Mbps and low latency. The passengers want to stream Netflix." "Dr. Lars, and i must object," I replied. "Passengers do not need 'Streaming'. They need 'Compliance'." "Why did we not wait for the European alternative, IRIS¬≤? It is scheduled to be operational by 2030 (maybe). It will offer 12 Mbps, cost ‚Ç¨50 per hour, and require a Post-Ident verification via webcam to log in." "That is the European way." "Instead, you choose the American Cowboy solution." "Fast. Cheap. Functional." "Disgusting." "Have you performed a Transfer Impact Assessment (TIA) for the data packets leaving the aircraft fuselage? The troposphere is technically a third-country jurisdiction." "If I send an email over the Atlantic using a Starlink terminal, is my metadata being harvested in Texas? Where is the Schrems II compliance?" She offered me a glass of Champagne to make me stop talking. I accepted. "I will use the Starlink Wi-Fi," I whispered. "But I will browse with a VPN set to Bielefeld." We may be flying at 35,000 feet. But our data must remain grounded.

content: @akaNemsko @HansMokeNiemann Sure, akaNemsko! Here's Hans's story reformatted with paragraph breaks for easier reading: I wanted to share a behind the scenes story of what the life of a chess player is really like. Before Wijk Aan Zee, I decided to stop in Vienna on the way to Wijk Aan Zee and I conveniently found a very reasonably priced business class ticket. My trip started rather smoothly, I arrived to the airport early, but when I tried to enter the airport they asked me for a printed version of my boarding pass. I had no wifi, but thankfully a fan recognized me so I offered to take a photo if he shared his hotspot. Alas, I managed to enter the airport where after checking in they told me that because of an equipment shortage they changed aircrafts and had demoted me from business to economy. After lengthy discussions they finally explained that the original plane had 14 business class seats while the new one only had 8 so 6 passengers got the unlucky draw. Regardless, they were accommodating and blocked off an entire row in economy so it was still uncomfortable. Obviously I would not consider this a travel nightmare, but this was only the beginning. I arrived in Abu Dhabi, and was looking forward to the far more comfortable seat on the flight to Vienna. However, shortly before arriving, the captain announced "10 minutes until landing", but 30 minutes passed and we didn't land. They eventually announced that due to the weather we had to circle Vienna until we got permission to land. After circling for an hour, the plan was to go to Munich but we were eventually rerouted to Frankfurt. Before we got off the plane in Frankfurt, they told us that the same plane would take us to Vienna at 8pm later that evening. However I saw that there was an 11:45 flight on an earlier airline so I booked that and thought that I could save time. Of course, 1 hour before it's departure, it was cancelled, and all other flights to Vienna were full. Lufthansa automatically rebooked me on a flight to dusseldorf, and then to Vienna. I mean after 24h of travel, continuous cancellations, money wasted. I decided to take the flight to dusseldorf then Vienna which eventually arrived at 7pm. While you might think that this entire story is incredibly negative, this is actually a great omen for my future chess results. Whenever similar travel nightmares occurred, especially during the pandemic, amazing results would follow. So the real moral of the story is that all of my bad luck is gone and that everything should hopefully go my way.

content: ELON MUSK VS RYANAIR: WHEN EGOS TAXI DOWN THE RUNWAY ‚úàÔ∏è‚ö° This started as a throwaway insult. It‚Äôs now flirting with a $35 billion headline. Elon Musk asked his followers on X whether he should buy Ryanair ‚Äî not to grow aviation, but to fire its CEO. The spark? Ryanair boss Michael O‚ÄôLeary publicly mocked Musk, saying he knows ‚Äúzero about planes‚Äù and dismissed Starlink as expensive drag that burns fuel and money. Think of it like this: üîπ One man sells rockets, satellites, and ambition. üîπ The other sells ‚Ç¨9.99 seats and insults ‚Äî at scale. Musk fired back the only way Musk knows how: A poll. A joke. And a not-so-joking suggestion that he might just buy the airline. The poll hit 30 million views. Markets barely blinked. Why? Because reality still exists. üî∏ EU airlines must be majority EU-owned üî∏ Non-EU shareholders can‚Äôt even vote üî∏ Ryanair is heading toward being debt-free üî∏ And Musk already has Tesla shares pledged from buying Twitter This isn‚Äôt a takeover. It‚Äôs theatre. And both men know it. Ryanair trolls back. Musk escalates. The internet eats it up. It‚Äôs like two pub fighters throwing punches across the bar ‚Äî knowing full well the bouncer (regulation, capital, gravity) isn‚Äôt letting it turn into a real fight. üü¢ FINAL THOUGHT This was never about WiFi. It‚Äôs about dominance, attention, and narrative control. In markets, investors ignore noise. In media, noise is the product. And right now, both men are flying first class on it. (Source: Financial Times) #Markets #Aviation #Power
